review_title: Strong Company but Set In Its Ways
pros:
- Recognized Fortune 100 market leader
- Products are neat, they have an impact in the world
- Generous pay, attractive bonuses in good years
- Comprehensive benefits, employees are very well taken care of
- My group was pretty consistently 40-45 hour weeks
- There is a career pipeline and they try to help your personal growth (but along with it can come some politics and limited options)
- People were very professional and pleasurable to work alongside. Some amazing managers
cons:
- Very traditional and serious culture. Lack of youth and trouble attracting/retaining new talent in recent years
- Aged systems, procedures, red tape that stifles innovation and sometimes grinds work to a halt
- Company is so large that things are siloed and cross-functional projects can be a pain. Oftentimes information/data has to be pried from another group or is just not worth the time to obtain
- A noticeable number of people are there to "put food on the table". You can run into roadblocks trying to go above & beyond and make change happen. An "exceeds" expectations performance rating is too high a barrier, results in burnout unless you crave the work
- The workload is heavy and ever increasing. After years of asking for more headcount or improved systems/technology, there's been acknowledgement but no action
- Leadership preaches "pay for performance", which it does with bonuses. But regular compensation is largely a "put your time in" system. If asked to perform a role above your level, they'll "write down" the role on paper and pay you based on your years of experience to do the more demanding work. Colleagues have been asked to cover work above their level for an extended timeframe, then asked to approve the hiring paperwork to pay someone else significantly more money to do it
- The divisional leadership preaches "flexibility" and changing the way we work, but seems to have blinders on, or an agenda. We're encouraged to find a balance between our needs and the business needs - by eliminating work remote and picking 2+ days to be in the office. This is after two successful years of full remote work in which every 3 months we were told we'd return, then delayed.. and everyone was kept nearby on a leash. Some jobs have no practical reason to be in person and their stakeholders are everywhere across the globe except for the office where the role is based.
